body.p: The find utility can be used to search for and perform commands upon groups of files matching a given set of criteria. The basic usage is find path rules.
For portability purposes, always specify a path. Do not rely upon find defaulting to the current working directory if no path is provided.

tr.ti: Only find files named blah. The * and ? wildcards may be used but should be quoted as in -name 'blah*'.
Only find files not named blah.
Find only regular files, not directories.
Find only files belonging to user foo. It is best to use named users rather than numeric UIDs. In particular, root may not be UID 0 on some systems.
Find only files belonging to group foo. It is best to use named groups rather than numeric GIDs.
Only descend 3 levels into subdirectories. -maxdepth 1 will ignore all subdiretories of the specified path.
Ignore the first 2 directory levels before a match occurs. -mindepth 1 will process all files except the command line arguments.
Execute a command. {} is replaced replaced by the name of the current matched file. See examples below.
Same as -exec but runs the command from within the basedir of the match.

body.note: EAPI>=5 assumes GNU find, so it is safe to use GNU extensions in ebuild context for those EAPIs.
body.p: By default, find will echo a list of matching files to the standard output. This can be used in a while loop:
body.codesample: while read f ; do einfo "Doing unholy things to ${f}" done < <(find "${S}" -type f)
body.p: Or a for loop (for small numbers of files):
body.codesample: for f in $(find "${S}" -type f) ; do einfo "Calling down holy vengance upon ${f}" done
body.warning: In both cases, files with weird characters or spaces in their names may cause serious problems.

When -exec is terminated by a ; character (needs escaping or quoting) then the command line is built seperately for every match. If it is terminated by a + character then the command line is built by appending each selected file name at the end.

body.warning: The -exec argument has security issues, because of race conditions (this is also true for find . -print0 | xargs ... constructs). This should not be a problem in ebuild context, because directories typically aren't writeable by random users. However you should consider -execdir as an alternative approach which runs the command from inside the basedir of the match (note that -execdir is not POSIX, see the table).
